Brevundimonas olei is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Brevundimonas, which is a member of the Proteobacteria phylum. It is a Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, and strictly aerobic bacterium.

Brevundimonas olei is known to be able to degrade and utilize oil as a carbon and energy source. It was first isolated from soil samples contaminated with oil in China. The cells of this species are typically rod-shaped, with a size range of 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.0-2.5 μm in length.

Biochemically, Brevundimonas olei is positive for catalase and oxidase activities. It can grow at temperatures ranging from 10°C to 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 30°C. The bacterium is able to tolerate a wide range of pH conditions, from 6.0 to 9.0, with an optimal pH around 7.0-8.0.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Brevundimonas olei is closely related to other Brevundimonas species, but it can be distinguished from them by its unique phenotypic and genotypic characteristics.

The ability of Brevundimonas olei to degrade oil makes it a potential candidate for bioremediation applications in oil-contaminated environments. Further research on its metabolic capabilities and ecological roles may provide insights into its environmental significance and potential biotechnological applications.
